reviewText: As expected, Samurai Champloo has some elements that are very similiar to Cowboy Bebop. Mugen looks and acts a lot like Spike. It wouldn't suprise me at all if Spike was Mugen's reincarnation since they both are bold, arrogant, and angry all the time. Another thing that is similiar is the music does not fit with the time period at all, but it still fits with the punk attitude of the show. Those two things are obviously not new. I also have to admit that the content is sometimes a little cliche- namely the episode with the giant ogre man who actually is sweet inside.On to the good parts of the show- there is plenty of sword fighting action and blood. The violence is not too bad but there were a few times I couldn't help but to cringe. The first few episodes don't spend too much time expanding on the main plot- about the guy who smells like sunflowers. These episodes try to give an impression of the three main characters in several different conflicts- mainly men trying to take control of the people.None of the shows were revolutionary in plot, but they were all entertaining. The music is awesome, probably the best anime music I've heard in long long time. And the animation is top notch also. There is even a little humor in the show, and all of the main characters are likeable. I was a little afraid I would find Fuu annoying since the description says she is a little nutty, but it isn't to the extreme. The show has everything a viewer wants except for the lack of moving on with the main plot. This is the main problem I had. Other than that, I really enjoyed these first four episodes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This has to be one of the coolest animes ever made. With the Director of Cowboy Beebop, the creators of the series have turned history on its head, as we join Mugen, Jin, and Fuu on their road trip in Meji-period Japan. Mugen, with his rough and ready back street fighting skills, and Jin, with his uncompromising elegant swordsmanship, help the young waitress in her journey to find the "Samurai who smells of sunflowers" in return for her saving them from execution, while also trying to find enough food to eat along the way.The most impressive aspect of this series as a whole is in its ability to change from heart-breaking storylines to extremely funny episodes. This anime shows us a totally different historical Japan, one that has the walking dead, baseball, and nude paintings. However, it grounds itself by also showing us the emotional background stories of the characters and the people they meet along the way. You really never ever know what to expect from one episode to the next, so the series is always fresh and never gets boring.The animation is very good and the creators have put a lot of effort to ensure their characters have detailed facial expressions. The voice acting is spot-on, with Mugen's attitude coming across brilliantly and the music is good. I love the song on the ending credits, however, the opening hip-hop tune takes a bit of getting used to. This is on of the top animes out at the moment and deserves to match the success of Cowboy Beebop.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's rare that I decide to buy a anime series outside a box set. I hate waiting for new releases in the series, and I'm never happy with the number of episodes on the DVD. And then Samurai Champloo came along. It has innovation from the opening seconds to the final seconds, with an animation quality not often found in twenty-six episode series.I've yet to find an episode that I don't like, and I don't mind waiting for the next because I know I won't be disappointed. Rivals Cowboy Bebop in style, taking on a hip-hop mode rather than the jazzy mode that Cowboy Bebop follows, this style seems to guide the episodes on, leaving you laughing along the way. Great animation, great soundtrack, great characters--though not entirely original--all add up to one great anime series, one worth buying in sequense as they are released.I'd recommend to anime fans, and if that's too broad then I recommend Samurai Champloo to fans of Cowboy Bebop, Wolf's Rain, or Trigun, as all of these anime seem to have a style all their own, something that is shared in Champloo.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Mugen: an undisciplined mixed martial artist from a Japanese Penal colony island.Jin: a disciplined, calculating, Ronin who killed his master.Fuu: a young orphaned girl looking for in her own words "A samurai who smells of sunflowers,"The three are an unlikely trio, each more different then the last. Both Jim and Mugen were slated to die because some noble's son got killed in a fire. Fuu, manages to save the two and makes them a deal. If the coin they flip is one side they help her if not they fight it out with each other. The three go off through Japan meeting up with new people and those from their own lives. They face warrior monks, at least three different Yakuza factions, meet up with a gay Dutch East India Company representative, play baseball against a crew from a U.S. streamer, and facing off against feirce opponents. Mugen and Jin both meet up with the women of their dreams, and all the while grill Fuu about who their looking for. At the end of the series the three end up at a cross roads and Fuu tells them that she lied about the results of the coin toss, the two of them looking at her in disbeleif. Because of her they dined and dashed, jumped a checkpoint, killed people, and managed to kill at least two of the Japanese shoganutes best assasins. So its safe to say their number one on the most wanted list of Japan, but instead of being mad the two after watching her walk away part as well. Fuu learning how to rely on herself, Jin learning that a lord isn't worth fighting for but your freinds are always worth suffering and dying for, and Mugen learning a thing or two about love and peace. A great anime.
summary: Samurai Champloo, one of the greats.
Title: N/A

reviewText: An anime by known director Shinichiro Watanabe (the mastermind behind Cowboy Bebop), Samurai Champloo is one of the best anime series to date for a number of reasons. Not only does it blend traditional with the not-so-traditional rival Japanese styles but it provides the audience with hours of memorable entertainment.At first I wasn't sure whether or not I wanted to see Samurai Champloo. From seeing a few clips on Adult Swim, I thought the series was just a bunch of beautifully drawn and animated sequences slapped together with the guise of pulling in those solely interested in hip-hop music, and interested in watching funny animes. Admittedly at the time the hip-hop wasn't the type of hip-hop they play on contemporary radio, and still it took many months to finally watch Samurai Champloo.Man... I've never been so wrong about a television series in my entire life.While Samurai Champloo is extremely funny at times, humor isn't what the series is about. While the series offers a lot of great acid-jazz type music (jazz with a lot of synthesized segments thrown in), the series isn't even about that. Those searching for a children's anime, look elsewhere... although the series offers quite a bit of engrossing action sequences, this anime is for fans of the genre with an appreciation for a great performance.If Cowboy Bebop was amazing, Samurai Champloo is groundbreaking in its great storyline and mix of everything good about a quality anime production.The series is literally a superb anime with a great, gripping storyline, one with plenty of emotional content and some of the best animated segments in the business! Such scenes are bested only by deep characters whose background stories as well (as well as appearance), will leave you overjoyed. Richly colored characters and backgrounds mark this anime as something different from the standard Samurai-enemy-slaying show.Simply put Samurai Champloo is an anime series with a hell of a lot of soul and its worth checking out. However I would not recommend this particular box set as it doesn't seem worth the price, but do yourself a favor and find the series in its entirety: you won't be sorry.

reviewText: First off, I'll admit that the characters themselves are cliche.  But given that this is only the first released DVD, I was willing to give it a chance.  The animation itself is very stylish and well done as expected from the creators of Cowboy Bebop.  And the soundtrack, wow!!  The music is what really completes this series.  I purchased the dvd with the soundtrack and ended up listening to the soundtrack 4 times in a row.  If you like hip hop music and anime, this will definitely appeal to you.  Again, while the characters themselves aren't original, the combination of music and animation style make this anime worthwhile.  Hopefully, later in the series the characters will grow.

reviewText: This anime starts out really really cool.  I liked the animation style and the colors.  The problem with this anime though is that it gets old really fast.  Most all the episodes I saw had the travelers stumbling into a town hungry, pawning weapons for food, acting out the plot, then earning their weapons back.  It happened over and over again without ever furthering the story.  I could'nt really take it any more.  Also, beatboxing breakdancing samurai is kinda pushin it.  There are much better samurai animes out there.

reviewText: Unlike the main characters in this awesome anime from the director of Cowboy Bebop and the guy who did the Kill Bill anime short - anime fans will not be left feeling empty. Only longing for more after viewing this first 4 episode filled DVD of goodness. There have been few action-based anime series that I personally could get into after Cowboy Bebop (which I define on my personal preferences as the best series of all anime). Sure, I enjoyed Trigun. Hellsing. Outlaw Star. But none of them held sway over me as much as Bebop did. In clashes Samurai Champloo like the swip of a katana. Leaving you wanting to see more.The actual DVD itself is done of the same calibre quality of most other popular animes. I personally enjoy watching any action-based anime with English Dubs - and the voice actors in Champloo are pretty much the same ones that did Bebop and other popular anime series dubs. The dubbing is top notch on Champloo so far. The picture and sound quality are also as awesome, especially on a 6.1 Surround/Dolby setup.The box set is lacking though. The bandana is cheesy schwag, but the collectors box itself is at least worth it, though not worth paying an extra $20 to get it.If you love action anime, samurai or just were a big fan of Cowboy Bebop - you'll love Samurai Champloo.
summary: Action anime fans left hungry no more.

reviewText: One of the most popular animes as far as having a more universal appeal aside from just anime fans in general is Cowboy Bebop. While not as marketable (i.e videogames, trading cards and the like reserved for Yu-Gi-Oh!, Naruto or Inuyasha), it was filled with likable characters, great soundtracks and a rarity in most animes: compelling one-off episodes or stand alones. So of of course director Shinichiro Watanabe has got to feel the pressure for his follow-up right? Probably not as immensely entertaining, Samurai Champloo is a treat in its own right.The tale centers on 3 main characters: Mugen, a sort of rough-and-tumble guy who uses hip-hop moves and a more, shall we say, graceful sloppiness in his fighting? His rival/friend is Jin, very cold and introverted with the swordsmanship of a trained master. One day, they meet Fuu, a young teahouse waitress who asks of them a favor: to find a samurai that smells of sunflowers. Why that particular samurai? And why the smell? All will be answered...eventually.First, let's talk about the music. Yes, the music is primarily hip-hop and it's strangely enough, a kind of successful blend to the point where you don't even notice it after awhile. Sure you'll raise an eyebrow when you play the first episode and its rap-flavored song comes through the speakers but eventually the music is just part of the scenery. One thing to note though as far as the characters are concerned is that while good characters on their own, you can't help but feel shades of their spiritual predecessors. Mugen looks like Spike Spiegel's grittier unemployed brother that pops in while drunk and there's shades of Faye Valentine in Fuu.Like a lot of top premier anime titles, Samurai Champloo is quite something to see in motion. Just like Samurai 7, the animation is very vibrant with attractive looking characters and a fluidity to it all. As for its story, the idea of a Sunflower-smelling samurai sounds kind of silly but it does give the story a go ahead for something to find out unlike in most anime where the main arc doesn't kick in until halfway. In this disc you'll see the initial rivalry between Mugen and Jin as well as the people who try to exact revenge or just being hired by the wrong people.Walk into this thinking you're going to see a cool anime and you'll walk out feeling that way. Just don't expect you're walking into a Cowboy Bebop part II, unless you hate that show which is just funny to me but oh well, to each their own.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After reading several raving reviews of Samurai Champloo I knew I had to get my hands on this series. Especially being a fan of Cowboy Bebop I was looking forward to the same high quality character interaction, animation, and music. And yes, it delivered on all accounts. First of all the music definitely captures the mood of the series although I'm not running out the door to grab the soundtrack, it does compliment the series nicely. Second of all , the animation is the best I've seen in a t.v. series in a long time. It is incredibly fluid and the characters just glide across the screen like it's the most natural thing in the world. This is especially apparent in the simple but well choreographed action scenes that bless this series. Last of all, the character interactions are off to a shakey but decent start with solid foundations for something intriguing to build on. I'm definitely interested by how the characters will flesh out and develop over the course of the show .
Title: N/A

reviewText: You can't fight it--anything directed by Shinichiro Watanabe will always have the label "from the makers of Cowboy Bebop." That said, "Samurai Champloo" is a definite five-star effort...as long as you don't expect it to match the greatness that is "Cowboy Bebop." Set in post-feudal Japan, "Champloo" modernizes the samurai story, throwing in hip-hop elements such as beatboxing (acapella-style hip-hop beats), dyed, modern hairstyles, breakdancing, graffiti, etc. The "heroes?" Two powerful swordsmen and a teen waitress, cutting through Japan in search of the samurai who smells like sunflowers.Mugen: streetbrawler, no style or form, samurai mixed with breakdancer (think Eddie from Tekken crossed with...a swashbuckling pirate), with a soul as evil as it is good. He hails from the Japanese equivalent of old Australia, an island where criminals are cast off or wash up on. He fights relying heavily on his lightning-quick instincts, with a sword-style less disciplined than his hairstyle. He has been near death so many times that he converses with the grass-cloaked figures that appear in the moment before death, as if they were old friends. Not much of a back story: he grew up a criminal, and continues to live like one.Jin: Your classic kimono-clad samurai, with a lightning fast sword, dismembering opponents before they can even draw. Where Mugen is brash, crude and brainless, Jin is cool, gentlemanly and intelligent. He does carry a lot of baggage: so skilled as a child that he could not make friends, and so morally-rooted that he had to kill his own master. The result? Samurai after samurai seeking to test their skills on him or avenge Jin's former teacher.Fuu: The idealistic teenage waitress, blinded by the usual sensitivities of that age. She rescues both Jin and Mugen from a botched execution; in exchange, the must help her find her "samurai who smells of sunflowers." She is mentally strong, but truly a ditz: she loses the finals of an eating contest by slapping her hands together to kill a fly that has been bothering her, accidentally making the "give up" sign.The "Champloo" style is cool. Disc-scratching, beats, and blurry-style camera movement (think fight scenes from "Cowboy Bebop" and CB the Movie) make for awesome imagery and battles. The cons? The story doesn't hold as tightly together, and goes all over the place, which makes for an adventurous, but schizophrenic series. Also, the humor and "flashback episodes" can be tiresome and childish.Why doesn't it hold up to "Bebop?" In a word, the ending. Where there were numerous "threads" holding Bebop together (each character's back story constantly surfacing against the threat of the villain Vicious), Champloo's characters lack depth and meet fewer interesting characters than the Bebop crew. So where Bebop's story builds and builds to a beautiful climactic ending, Champloo can only stagger to one.Highly recommended. Just forget the label "from the makers of Cowboy Bebop."
summary: Don't Hold It Up To Bebop

reviewText: WOW! that's one word that comes to mind. WOW! ever since tenchi muyo was taken off the air, their has not been any anime shows that have interested me. for years i searched, never finding anything worth watching. then, i sort of gave up. i would occasionaly check adult swim for any signs of a new great anime but to no avail. then one night it happened: i saw the second episode of Samurai Champloo air on adult swim. at first, i wasnt paying attention to the words and action. i was looking at what had caught my eye when i was flipping channels: THE ANIMATION! the artwork was incredible!the colors that were used to draw the characters and the world they were interacting in made it seem real. it was almost as if it was a sitcom, with real people. only tis was completly animated. it was eye-popping!then, i started to watch the show itself and the show was great!!! anyway, since then i have been addicted to the series and i have six of the volumes. but alas, the last one (number seven) comes out this month on the 17th. the show is coming to an end. so anyway, im going to write reviews for each of the volumes and rate them. i rated volume one of samurai champloo below:episode one: tempestuous temperaments- jin, mugen and fuu meet for the first time. mugen is looking for a challenge and hears about three "bad asses" and sends some cowards to go get them. mugen however, does not know that jin has killed them already. mugen mistakes jin as one of the "bad asses" and attatcks him. a brilliant fight insues, and jin mugen and fuu end up travling together.i rate episode one a 10/10episode two: redeye reprisal-  mugen cut a mans arm off in episode one. in this episode, the man is out for revenge. the man recruits an ogre by the name of oniwaka to help him exact revenge on mugen. also, jin encounters a highly skilled assasin who has been hired to kill him. another great fight. and last of all, our modest (cough) fuu gets smashed.i rate this episode 9/10episodes 3 & 4: hellhounds for hire part one and two- the three heros part ways but fate eventually brings them back together. jin is hired by a gang as a bodygaurd. mugen is hired as a bodyguard by a rival gang. fuu is tricked into capture and is forced to work in a broffel house.i give both episodes 3&4 10/10thats the end of my review for volume one of samurai champloo.if you are new to the series check out my reviews for each volume to see if you want to get the volumes. i will say this, they are really expensive. but they are worth the money. i get them at best buy and they are 24.99 plus tax and each volume has four episodes on it. if you have not bought this dvd and are debating weither it is good or not, i reccomend you buy it. i can personally vouch for this dvd. of course, its always good to check other reviews by different people as well.later.i hope this review helped.
summary: Mugen's the name pal, you got that?
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, Shinichiro Watanabe did only 1 episode on the Animatrix (the crummiest one). Second, I liked Bebop, though sometimes I felt that the fillers tried to be a bit over-cool. Look, Watanabe, Tarantino, if you aint got a good plot and story to hang all that cool on, even cool gets old, and Samurai Champloo did, in a hurry!from the start we are bombarded with hip hop beats and "cool" dialogue and cursing. I thought the fighting, (what little of it there was) was cool, pop-locking and spinning on the ground, but what was the point? Also, the animation lagged at a lot of points and the level of detail, compared to say a Ninja Scroll was sketchy. At times it looked like the animators just said the hell with it and did some of the scenes with magic markers. I don't see any plot whatsoever except for "sunblossoms" or whatever the hell it is they are supposed to be seeking. The first DVD was ok, the second DVD is even crummier. The animation looks just a shade better than South Park, and that's no kidding. The character are abstractly rendered and the stories, if you can call them that, are weak attempts by the director and animators to be funny and cool. The most irritating thing about this anime is the cut scenes which are synced to record scratches. Totally pointless. And as I mentioned before, the animation gets crummier with each episode. If you like style, record scratches, cussing, no plot, an occasional pop-lock or karate kick check out this series. And while you're at it, check out Kill Bill 3 by that other ultra-cool, ultra-hip director.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are bored with Kurosawa's faithful decpition of historical Samurai (and who would be?), if you think the Samurai genre has been overused and outdated...then get ready for the hip-hop remix version of the age old genre: SAMURAI CHAMPLOO.  Directed by Shinichiro Watanabe, the man who brought us Cowboy Bebop and 2 shorts in Animatrix, with character design by Kazuto Nakazawa, Kill Bill vol. 1 fame, we are treated to a world that would have made the Wu-Tang Clan feel right at home.  The action is off the wall with the two main characters treating us to two styles of fighting that are the very antithesis to each other. One follows the strict laws of bushido while the other adheres to a style that can only be described as being the breakdance of sword play.  The music is all modern hip-hop, no moody asian flare here.The story is about the adventures of these two warriors as they escort a pessant girl across Japan in search of a samurai who's only distinquishing characteristic is that "he smells like sunflowers."  Lack of money, food, and patience is a recipe for disaster and wacky hi-jinks in this adventure-comedy.  Rated 16+ (the equivilent of R in the US) for bloody violence and language.  A must for any samurai genre fan.

reviewText: I love Cowboy Beebop. For me it was a flawless series because it was funny but not annoying anime cliche's with clumsy lines. Samurai champloo in the other hand has many flaws but still a good attempt at capturing the Cowboy beebop stylish rich culture. Iv seen my share of animes and i can point out all the flaws in this seriese. First of all the female lead character is realy annoying(like in many other anime series before it) and keeps C**k blocking both samurai characters in thier prime scenes. Right of the bat on the first dvd not all episiods are realy that entertaining like in cowboy beebop nor that funny as intended. This whole "lets get in each others faces and fight each other again" between both lead samurai characters becomes realy old and cliche after 2 or 3 episiodes. However fighting scenes to pick up some of the slack so does the style it's animated. So if ur looking for another perfect anime like Cowboy beebop all i got to say is , smoke but no ciggar.

reviewText: I've noticed that several sites dealing with anime have called this mediocre Samurai anime.  I've never watched much anime, truthfully, I've never really been exposed to it.  But I started watching this series over the summer and I loved it.  I think I have the distinction of being the only person on the face of the earth who was turned onto Cowboy Bebop through Samurai Champloo, and not the other way around.  This disc contains the first four episodes of the series.The first episode, "Tempestous Temperments" introduces all three characters.  Mugen, the angry, undisciplined street fighter, Jin, the disgraced, calm, samurai, and Fuu, the airheaded waitress, (She's only pretending;).  When Mugen and Jin are arrested for burning down the tea house Fuu works in, she realizes that she could use their help, and in turn, offers to help them escape their death sentance.  However, we see they don't really need her.The second episode, "Redeye Reprisal," is one of my favorites.  It tells us a little more about the characters.  Fuu is kidnapped and held hostage by a man with a score to settle with Mugen, who is off being seduced by a very forward woman.  Unfortunately, she's not after Mugen because he's so attractive...The third episode is the first of a two part, episode, called "Hellhounds For Hire."  Mugen and Jin ditch Fuu and the three end up in the same village, Mugen and Jin working for rival criminal organizations, and Fuu in a brothel.  The Second part of the episode features Mugen going back to rescue Fuu, which he always ends up doing, only to find she can actually take care of herself.  There's a lot more to this episode than I've written here, because it's fairly complicated, and I don't want to spoil anything.The series is very good.  If you liked Cowboy Bebop, but didn't like how sad it was, this is definately for you.  This is light, and it's good, plus it actually has very funny moments.

reviewText: Three people, Mugen as the wild warrior, Jin a well-mannered swordmaster, and Fuu a ditzy waitress, meet together and the adventure starts.  Directed by Shinchiro Watanabe (Cowboy Bebop, Animatrix), designed by Kazuto Nakazawa (Kill Bill Vol 1) and Mahiro Maeda (Last Exil, Vlue Submarine 6) this isn't your grandfather's anime.  Not only is the music hot, the artwork perfect, but even the English voice cast is great.  Mugen is voiced by Daniel Andrews( also known as Steven Jay Blum), Fuu is voiced by Kari Wahlgren and Jin is voiced by Kirk Thornton and we also have Wendee Lee, Steve Kramer, Lex Lang, Darrel Guilbeau and Tony Oliver as some of the backup voices.Think Cowboy Bebop in Japan during the Age of War.

reviewText: I've been waiting for this for a while. I loved Cowboy Bebop and looked forward to more from the creators. Here it is and it doesn't disappoint.The 1st DVD starts off with our three heroes (?) meeting quite by acceident (isn't that how it always happens?). In fact, they start out looking to kill each other, if not for the girl that saves them and makes them promise to help her find "the samurai that smells of sunflowers". Thus, the journey and the series begins. The art style is very nice and clean looking. The violence is usually hidden by using shadows that are cut, in half usually. On this first DVD, the shows are light, sometimes funny. The interaction between our heroes is what keeps the shows interesting.The music for the series also sets it apart (as it did with Cowboy Bebop). Mostly hip hop music and it's very upbeat and goes well with the action.I'm impressed by this first DVD and am looking forward to seeing more!

reviewText: Before I say anything else .. this is gotta be one of the best anime I've ever seen! I'm not an anime expert or anything, but I know a good anime when I see it, and this is definitely a GREAT one. Samurai Champloo has a uniqueness to it, and that's  the reality of the storyline, and probably the soundtrack. The characters: Mugen(the badass, rebel swordsman); Jin(the cool, calm and collected samurai) and Fuu(the funny/dummy waitress) are not something original .. in fact its very common in anime. But the soundtrack is amazing! I'm not a fan of hip hop but when I first saw the anime, the music fits perfectly to the fight scenes and pretty much every second of the series. The skiping of the music (like a DJ would do) I thought it made the anime more exciting because the music complements every second of the anime!! It gets you in the mood man, really and I never thought i would say thi about hip hop, although when ur watching the anime the word HIP HOP is not sealed to your mind, it blends with the anime and they become one.The animation is also amazing. There are similarities between the animation in bebop and samurai champloo, obviously, but that's the good thing! The animation in bebop was great to begin with, but in this one is considerably improved. In the fight scenes specially you can see each and every single one of the movements the characters make, not like some other animes where you see only still images changing fast giving you the impression of movement. No, in this anime you actually see the characters move and is very real.The characters are likeble, hell I love them all! Mugen is really something(like spike) and he does have something unique which is the combination of break dancing with swordfighting. It is also so much fun to watch! the fights between him and Jin are the best ones,because they're both so goddamn good!!! Jin is strict and keeps his cool even when he's fighting. He's an amazing samurai and has a fixation with defeating Mugen. Even though he complains at Mugen for his reckless fighting, the reason he wants to beat Mugen is cuz he is the first man Jin has fought that he couldn't kill. They hate each other and have to work together lol. So tipical, yet so good.The story is pretty good, and it has a kind of weird humor to it since they're looking for the "man who smells like sunflowers" or something like that. It all starts when Fuu(a waitress) helps Mugen and Jin escape an execution(although they managed to free themselves without her) she does help em' at the end. So she makes them promise to help her find this man that smells like sunflowers, who's supposed to be a samurai. Starting from the 1st episode you have a clear picture of what's going on and of the character's personalities. It really is an amazing anime, its fun, fast paced and has a twisted sense of humor. ;-)
summary: Now, this is something you want to see

reviewText: Samurai Champloo is the long-awaited next project from Cowboy Bebop director Shinichiro Watanabe.  His two short films in the Animatrix compilation (Kid's Story and Detective Story) give American audiences a sneak peek at the phenomenal art style of this series, but they barely hint at the jaw-dropping action and unorthodox blend of history and music contained therein.The first four episodes of Champloo introduce its three protagonists: the vagrant swordsman Mugen, the rogue samurai Jin, and the tea-shop waitress Fuu.  This unlikely and volatile trio begin a road journey through post-shogunate Japan (ca. 1780), brought together by circumstances best seen to be believed."Champloo" means mixed-up or stir-fry, and that's what this series is: a stylish blend of old school values and situations, meshed with more modern sensibilities, fighting styles, and visual design.  Over the lush, dynamic art, a soundtrack of some of the best hip-hop from modern Japan plays.  Though it's a noticeable device in the first few episodes, it doesn't take long before the music feels like second nature despite the anachronism.Champloo is many things: a mature drama, an action series, an uproariously funny comedy and a visual feast.  Watanabe-san demonstrates here that the success of Cowboy Bebop was uniquely his, and no fluke - fans of that series will not be disappointed, despite how radically different the two storylines are from one another.As the first title card of the first episode of Samurai Champloo says, "Just shut up and watch."
summary: Stylish genre- and era-bending action from Watanabe
Title: N/A

reviewText: Everywhere I look, I see Samurai Champloo being touted in magazine articles and anime news sites as the "Next Big Thing". While it has its moments, Champloo is woefully lacking in character and originality. It falls into the world of cliche upon cliche. It's a real shame.The 3 main characters of Mugen, Jin, and the ever clumsy woman character stereotype, Fuu, are all introduced in this volume. Mugen is kinda the rules breaking, unkempt Kurosawan, take no prisoners tough guy whose mouth and cockiness always lead him into trouble. A kind of trouble in which cutting people in half with a samurai sword usually solves. Jin is quieter and more refined, more samurai-like, with a conscience, but still willing to bow to noone. Two characters like this are bound to clash but for the inteference of Fuu, a waitress who TRIES to save Mugen and Jin after  they are slated for execution by a corrupt governor. In return, she imposes a truce between the two and says they cannot fight until they help her find the enigmatic "samurai who smells like sunflowers". Oh boy, here we go with another Yoda-like aphorism to describe a mystery that will probably be 25 episodes in coming. Hello! Just give us a description, a name, an address, so we can get his over with!! In this first volume the three will have to fight against rival gangs of Yakuza, chop some people up, and fight Frankenstein's monster.I was excited with the first episode, but after that this volume was pretty much downhill. In the second episode, a vengeful gang member sics a misshapen giant onto the trail of Mugen in a gross appropriation of Frankenstein, Of Mice and Men, and the Phantom of the Opera. I would also say that this monstrosity that only needs to be hugged by Fuu is also an insult to all the illiterate and abused cave trolls in the Lord of the Rings Trilogy. The last two part episode, "Hellhounds for Hire", rips off Kurosawa by having the Mugen and Jin arriving in a city divided by two rival gangs, a la Fistful of Dollars, in which, Surprise, Mugen and Jin, enter into the service of opposing sides. And all the while, Fuu's annoying diatribes scratch on my eardrums. Come on, I mean at least TRY to do something original.The only character that I enjoyed in this first volume was a flying squirrel that stays up Fuu's sleeve and helps her out in times of danger, by biting a would-be rapist's finger or landing on a obnoxious guard's face. Too bad he/she is only on-screen for a total of 10 seconds. I would say kill off all the characters and give the squirrel top billing! It might go a bit to redeeming this unpromising beginning of what I hoped would be a great series.The sound is good on this dvd: English 5.1, Japanese 2.0 and DTS and 16X9 Widescreen. Has a couple of trailers and a promo videoI would recommend Cowboy Bebop and any of Kurasawas samurai films in place of this anime.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Shinichiro Watanabe has taken the strange cultural mish-mash of "Cowboy Bebop" to the next step with "Samurai Champloo," which can be best described as a combination of "Zatoichi" (more specifically the recent Takeshi Kitano remake) and a Grand Master Flash album. There isn't a compelling story to go behind the self-aware hipness, but the style and fun characters make up for it. Then again, it's nice to see the samurai genre done in a very different kind of way. The first four episodes introduce us to the main characters (two of whom are on the same team but still want to kill each other) as they go about their business. There are some great gags here and it has potential, but I have a bad feeling that like many other anime series with a solid first volume, it will become less interesting as more episodes come out. Oh well, pick it up anyway. You'll have fun and if you're a compulsive anime watcher you'll end up watching it again and again.
summary: "Cowboy Bebop" with hip-hop and samurai? OK by me.

reviewText: Samurai Champloo pleases the eyes with it's odd sense of design.  The animation is a pleasure to watch.  The hip-hop soundtrack gives the old samurai drama a new twist and makes it fresh again.The story is focused on three misfits, and this first volume tells how they get together, and eventually set out on their mission to find a samurai who smells like sunflowers.  If you liked the series Cowboy Beebop, you'll probably enjoy this one a lot.  Certainly this is one of the better Japanese animation series to come out in a long time.  Check it out.

reviewText: "Champloo" is an Okinawan word (more properly pronounced champuru) meaning "mix" or "blend," and is most often applied to traditional food dishes such as "Goya Champloo" or "Stir-fried Champloo."  It's basically a  mixed stir-fry with a seemly infinite number of potential ingredient, and a very fitting description of Watanabe Shinichiro's new series "Samurai Champloo," an eclectic blend of ancient and modern, hip-hop and koto, and pretty much everything else thrown into the mix.Watanabe is a heck of a chef, and manages to balance such dissonant elements as a bookish but deadly Ronin (Jin), a wild sword-swinging roustabout (Mugen) and a kooky but determined waitress (Fuu) into a tasty dish worthy of his previous concoction "Cowboy Bebop."  Each ingredient supports the flavor of the other perfectly, creating a variety of story possibilities that couldn't be found by following just one personality.  Hip-hop music sets the background for a Japan where a wild swordfighter uses capoeira  moves to slice and dice with a fury, and an enormous man known as the Oni smashes skulls with his massive club.This first DVD sets the stage accordingly, with the trio being pushed into an unhappy alliance, attempting to split up, and finding their destinies inexorably intertwined.  Fuu leads them on a quest for the "Samurai who smells of Sunflowers," providing the McGuffin that keeps the story moving.Watanabe's trademark style is on fine display, with smooth animation and a quick and flowing story punctuated with quiet moments of reflection.  The story builds at a good pace, allowing all the characters to develop in time.  If "Cowboy Bebop" is anything to go by, we can expect quite the ride and explosive finish to "Samurai Champloo"
summary: A spicy dish served up hot!
